review.title: Recommending with an Agenda: Active Learning of Private Attributes using Matrix Factorization
review.abstract: Recommender systems leverage user social and demographic information, e.g., age, gender and political affiliation, to personalize content and monetize on their users. Oftentimes, users do not volunteer this information due to privacy concerns or to the lack of initiative in filling out their profile information. In this work, we illustrate a new threat in which the system can nevertheless learn the private attribute for those users who do not voluntarily disclose them. We design an active attack that solicit ratings for strategically selected items, and could thus be used by a recommender system to pursue its hidden agenda. Our method is based on a novel usage of Bayesian matrix factorization in an active learning setting. Evaluations, on multiple datasets, illustrate that such an attack is indeed feasible and can be carried out using significantly fewer rated items than the previously proposed static inference methods. Importantly, this threat can succeed without sacrificing the quality of the regular recommendations made to the user.
histories: This is the extended version of a paper that appeared in ACM RecSys 2014

sections.heading: 3.1 Problem Statement
sections.text: We consider a referral system, as illustrated in Figure 1, which provides a legitimate article referral service, but at the same time maliciously attempts to derive a private user attribute; the system has access to a record provided by non-privacy-sensitive users that contains article ratings and a categorical variable that we call a user type; the type is a private attribute such as gender, age, political affiliation, etc. A new user who is privacy-sensitive (i.e., his type is unknown) interacts with the system. The referral system actively presents elements that the user can evaluate, disguising it as a way to improve recommendations in the cold start setting. In this context, our goal is twofold: 1. We would like to design a type classifier that will detect the type of the user based on his or her ratings. We are trying to apply the latent factor model that prevails in the matrix factorization to determine the type of the article, 2. We would like to successfully evaluate the reliance system of the referral system under the assessment of the article type.

sections.heading: 6. EVALUATION
sections.text: In this section, we evaluate the performance of our methods using real data sets. We begin by describing the data sets and experiments, and then perform a comparative analysis of both passive and active methods.

sections.heading: 6.1 Experimental Setup
sections.text: We evaluate our method using three datasets: Movielens, Flixster [12], and Politics-and-TV (PTV) [25]. The Movielens dataset includes user ratings for movies in addition to gender and age of users. For convenience, we categorize the age group of users as young adults (ages 18-35) or adults (ages 36-65). Flixster is a similar rating system for users with at least 20 ratings and elements that contain user gender information. PTV includes ratings from U.S. users on 50 different TV shows, along with the gender and political affiliation of each user (Democrat or Republican). We pre-processed Movielens and Flixster to include only users with at least 20 ratings and elements rated by at least 20 users. Since PTV includes only 50 TV shows, we pre-processed the data to ensure that each user has at least 10 ratings. Table 1 summarizes the datasets used for rating.

sections.heading: 7. CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORK
sections.text: Our solution, which includes a mechanism for selecting the question to be asked of a user, as well as a classifier, is efficient in terms of both the number of questions asked and the runtime to generate each question. Going beyond binary attributes by using our classifier's relationship to the LDA is an interesting open question. Examining the attack from the user's perspective to better advise users on how to identify and potentially mitigate such attacks is also an important future direction.
